results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 7]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film captures a group trip by tourist bus, four wheel drive vehicles and truck around the ‘Gulf Country’. The Gulf Country is the region of woodland and savanna grassland surrounding the Gulf of Carpentaria in north western Queensland and parts of the Northern Territory, Australia.

We see many dirt roads and sandy tracks so that we see both a tourist bus and four wheel drive vehicles being dug out of the sand. As always, Wallace includes close-ups of any flora and fauna that catch
his eye along the way.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:03:00 titles ‘A Walkabout Film’, ‘Gulf Country’, ‘A WHC Film’
00:01:15:00 sign for ‘Four Wheel Drive’.
00:01:21:00 a large lorry style truck travelling ahead on dirt road.
00:01:31:00 digging a vehicle out of sand on a track.
00:02:30:00 tourist bus being hauled from the sandy track by a truck.
00:03:42:00 particularly colourful bird in a tree.
00:03:57:00 people in a small boat catching fish.
00:04:55:00 a row of tents for camping lined up along a riverbank.
00:07:45:00 close up of a blackened ‘billy can’ set over a fire and then a wider shot of a group of picnic-goers.
00:08:09:00 a woman in an example of a 1970s style ‘halter-neck’ top.
00:08:32:00 animal footprints in the dust followed by a large snake making progress through the grass
00:09:14:00 large truck and bus with baggage loaded on roof travel down a dusty road
00:09:57:00 cattle in stockyards
00:10:27:00 wetlands and wildflowers
00:11:45:00 swimming in a river
00:11:53:00 a close-up of a spider in the middle of a large web wit the blue of the river in the background
00:12:53:00 title card ‘The End’

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 6]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film, titled ‘Mountains of Mystery’, contains a trip around The Grampians National Park in Victoria. The filmmaker captures the various activities of visitors to the Grampians area as well as views across the mountains, an occasional bee, lizard, snake and echidna, trees, bush and wildflowers as well as the overall rocky terrain.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:03:00 titles ‘A Walkabout Film’, ‘Mountains of Mystery’ and ‘A WHC Film’
00:00:22:00 hikers on top of a huge log across a creek.
00:01:57:00 an echidna hiding in the bush.
00:02:05:00 hikers walking along a bush track.
00:07:20:00 instruction card for walkers and hikers.
00:07:55:00 sign to various locations in the Park.
00:08:06:00 hikers climbing up trails and narrow ravines among dramatic grey rocky outcrops followed by views from the summit.
00:09:57:00 a koala asleep in a tree
00:10:02:00 an intrepid hiker perched precariously on a high narrow rock ledge
00:10:39:00 plaque for ‘Makefing Reserve’ near the Grampians
00:11:00:00 signpost for ‘Makefing Rd’ (in two directions) and ‘Emmet Rd’ and ‘Stockyard…’ (which could be a sign to ‘Stockyard Hill’
00:11:19:00 park sign for ‘Major Mitchell Plateau’, ‘Mt William’, ‘Jimmy Creek’
00:12:29:00 hikers preparing a couple of ‘billy cans’ of tea and/or food on a small open fire
00:12:59:00 a hiker in all red gear including a woollen cap with a ‘pom pom’
00:13:45:00 scenes of hikers on steep tracks and then views from the summit
00:15:12:00 hikers gather around a boiling ‘billy’ on a small fire
00:15:40:00 sitting enjoying their tea
00:16:25:00 and echidna hiding in the grass
00:16:37:00 tree ferns followed by an old, plank footbridge over a creek
00:16:57:00 title card ‘The End’

results.title: Phantom Ride
results.credit_line:
Ian Potter Moving Image Commission, ACMI Collection

Daniel Crooks is represented by Anna Schwartz Gallery, Australia and Future Perfect, Singapore
results.brief_description: Daniel Crooks’ Phantom Ride alludes to cinema history to create a seamless journey through a composite reality. By manipulating digital footage as though it were a physical material, Crooks has constructed a collaged landscape, taking us through multiple worlds and shifting our perception of space and time.

constellations_primary.name: Taking it slow
constellations_primary.description: Daniel Crooks' Phantom Ride offers a meditative journey through digital landscapes that make the viewer pause and reflect.

constellations_other.name: Tracking cinema
constellations_other.description: A constellation looking at the evolution of the tracking / dolly shot.

results.description:
Daniel Crooks’ Phantom Ride alludes to cinema history to create a seamless journey through a composite reality. By manipulating digital footage as though it were a physical material, Crooks has constructed a collaged landscape, taking us through multiple worlds and shifting our perception of space and time.

“Phantom Ride comes out of my long-held fascination with the convergence of trains, the birth of cinema and modern ideas and representations of time.

I’ve presented it as a two-sided video; the forward-facing journey on one side and the rear looking journey on the reverse. The screen becomes a meniscus of the present, separating the past and the future.”

– Daniel Crooks
description_for_label:
Daniel Crooks’ Phantom Ride alludes to cinema history to create a seamless journey through a composite reality. By manipulating digital footage as though it were a physical material, Crooks has constructed a collaged landscape, taking us through multiple worlds and shifting our perception of space and time.

“Phantom Ride comes out of my long-held fascination with the convergence of trains, the birth of cinema and modern ideas and representations of time.

I’ve presented it as a two-sided video; the forward-facing journey on one side and the rear looking journey on the reverse. The screen becomes a meniscus of the present, separating the past and the future.” – Daniel Crooks
results.credit_line_for_label:
Ian Potter Moving Image Commission, ACMI Collection

Daniel Crooks is represented by Anna Schwartz Gallery, Australia and Future Perfect, Singapore

results.title: Australian Designers show their talents [excerpt from Australian Diary No. 007]
results.creator_credit: Jack S. Allan and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description:
We take a look back at some Australian designs from 1947. Woollen suits, sporty tennis outfits, debutantes gowns, plastic high-heeled shoes! hats and bridal wear are all paraded in this high-end extravaganza of Australian style.
Source: NFSA Film Australia Collection

results.title: 100 Pages
results.brief_description: ‘100 Pages’ is a project based upon the theme of North Sydney Girls High School’s Centenary. This project used the School’s identity and history as inspiration for artmaking. Through the artmaking, students are celebrating the school’s identity in the present and past community; isolating individual events, subjects and objects as inspiration. The title of the unit, ‘100 Pages’, comes from the initial idea of 100 animations, for 100 years of history. This project has been developed for the Stage 5 elective, Year 10 Photography and Digital Media class (PDM), which comprises 12 students from North Sydney Girls High School.

results.title: Time Machine [game trailer]
results.creator_credit: Werner van Niekerk, Cameron Cockrell and Tea Tree Gully Primary School
results.brief_description: ‘Time Machine’ is about robots that take over the world but there is a scientist that builds a robot that will take back the world. So it is your job to get past the boss. When you get past the boss you get a high score and the minions will try to kill you so watch out and have fun. There are bouncing pads that can help you jump higher and get things like health and score and save you too. There is also health which goes down when you are hit by evil robots or fireballs. Health packs increase your health.

results.title: Project Vena Cava [game trailer]
results.brief_description: ‘Project Vena Cava’ is an ambitious atmospheric first-person shooter with dark cinematic elements. Its storyline is science fiction themed and is delivered primarily through written documents found throughout the game, as well as a voiceover that accompanies the player throughout. It is similar in style to other sci-fi first-person shooters such as ‘Halo’, ‘Metroid Prime’ and ‘Portal’.

results.title: Transition
results.creator_credit: Rebecca Jordan, Sannah Maclean and Presbyterian Ladies' College
results.brief_description: Reflecting on the past can sometimes help you make sense of the present. An elderly man contemplates his life alone when the family are gone.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Rebecca Jordan, Sannah Maclean and Presbyterian Ladies’ College
results.description: Reflecting on the past can sometimes help you make sense of the present. An elderly man contemplates his life alone when the family are gone.

results.title: La Mia Vita = My Life
results.brief_description: An elderly Italian man decides to look through his photo album. This causes him to reflect on his life. From his youth, to his adolescence, through to his older years, the man looks back on the moments of his life that he treasures the most, and those that are very dear to his heart.

results.title: Sky's Adventure [game trailer]
results.creator_credit: Willow McFadzean, Parker Arnel and Hurstbridge Primary School
results.brief_description: ‘Sky’s Adventure’ is about a girl Sky and a mean girl Britney. Britney was never nice to anyone but she has to reflect on that when Sky says something to her. Will Britney change after reflecting on what she’s done or keep doing it?
results.creator_credit_for_label: Willow McFadzean, Parker Arnel and Hurstbridge Primary School
